awd_titl_txt: Identifying Barriers and Building Capacity: A Conference Series to Explore Factors that Lead to Increased Success in Securing External Funding for STEM Initiatives
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by identifying barriers facing Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) scholars, particularly those of color, in the successful creation and implementation of sponsored research funded activities. Two hybrid-delivered conferences will be held during the course of the project. Faculty and staff from open access two-year colleges, broad access four-year universities, Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), and other Minority Serving Institutions (MSI) will be invited to attend each conference. To ensure attendance by as broad an audience as possible, participants can select to attend virtually or face to face. Though other conferences have focused on providing information to faculty on how to write a competitive grant proposal, this conference is taking a more enriched approach. During the conference meetings faculty and staff will discuss potential barriers that exist within their institutions or their institutional systems that, if addressed, could improve successful grant writing and project implementation. Attendees at varying career levels and institutional types in STEM undergraduate education will be brought together to form a network of scholars focused on sharing best practices with regard to being successful in securing external funding. Model programs that have resulted in sustainable change at the institutional level will also be shared.

This project is building upon work through the Institute for the Contemporary African American Experience, an initiative at Cheyney University, a state HBCU in Pennsylvania. It is a well-documented phenomenon that though the number of people of color receiving STEM degrees of all levels (baccalaureate, masters, and doctorate) is increasing, the number of people of color in STEM who receive external support is decreasing. This conference seeks to better understand and address this phenomenon in several ways. First is to have participants engage in Racial Healing Circles for the purpose of identifying potential barriers, particularly for people of color, in securing sponsored research funds. Second is to create an authentic network of individuals dedicated to research and development in STEM education for the purpose of collaboration, mentoring, and increased understanding related to securing external research support. And third is to identify and share sustainable approaches to decreasing barriers and increasing support, particularly for people of color with regard to seeking and obtaining sponsored research funding. Targeted evaluation will occur with conference participants for the purpose of better understanding how activities like Racial Healing Circles, Mock Panels, Interactive Panels of Peers, and other activities can identify and address racial equity barriers and solutions. The findings will be disseminated to all attendees and their institutions through two follow-up virtual presentations, through targeted conference presentations, and publication of findings. Funding for this project is provided by the NSF IUSE: EHR Program which supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, the program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cheyney University of Pennsylvania's NSF-conference award (2133248) Breaking Barriers project, aimed to serve the national interest by identifying barriers facing Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) scholars, particularly those of color, in the successful creation and implementation of sponsored research-funded activities. Two conferences (one virtual 2021; one hybrid 2022) provided forums for faculty and staff from open-access two-year colleges, broad-access four-year universities, Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), and other Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs). Faculty and staff discussed potential barriers within their institutions and institutional systems that, if addressed, could improve successful grant writing and project implementation. Attendees at varying career levels and institutional types in STEM undergraduate education were brought together to form a network of scholarly professionals who shared best practices regarding securing external funding. Model programs that resulted in sustainable change at the institutional level were shared. One model featured undergraduate students connecting with STEM faculty and industry experts early in their STEM college studies establishing a basis for research and sponsored projects pursuits as they begin their STEM careers.  

Conferences advanced knowledge by using two critical DEI approaches to uncover challenges and derive solutions to break barriers for STEM scholars of color pursuing grant funding. Approach 1 in 2021: Healing circles were used to create safe spaces erasing micro-aggressive and unconscious bias behaviors allowing participants to share their experiences. No identifiable information was captured while the following challenges resonated throughout each of the healing circles formed:

Garnered from the healing circles and participants’ discussions was a need to develop and disseminate an evidence-based solution promoting micro-affirmative actions. Approach 2 in 2022: Restorative practices were used demonstrating how authentic networks can be created to promote mentorship and grant collaboration.

The conference consisted of four overarching themes, Community and Identity (42%), Perspectives, Challenges, and Strategies (24%), Networks of Support and Collaboration (22%), and Professional Development/Research (12%) (see SSSSS). Community and Identity was most prominent while least prominent theme was Professional Development/Research. Themes were mapped to the eight (8) short-term outcomes identified in the logic model leaders included in their NSF proposal (Table 1).

Eighty to ninety percent described the Conference as effective (‘Very effective’ and ‘Extremely effective’) across all three objectives. Two objectives scored high with respondents describing it as effective: ‘Helping you build authentic connections for career advancement’ (90.9%) and ‘Improving awareness of new NSF funding opportunities relevant to your work’ (90.9%).

When asked how the conference compared to their expectations/wants, 46.2% respondents said they ‘Got Everything I Wanted/ Expected’. Additionally 30.8% indicated they got a lot of what they wanted/expected. Participants described what they specifically learned. A few indicated they learned more about NSF’s priorities and the diversity of funding efforts. Others discussed learning the importance of providing research opportunities for minority students.

Direct responses examples:

  1. Benefits of mentorship and partnership for faculty of color.
  2. Diversity of NSF funding and its purposes.
  3. Enhanced my relationships with conference attendees and speakers.
  4. Exposing minority students to STEM career and graduate programs through pre-college program, education, research, and internships,
  5. Learned there is robust interest in efforts toward broader participation in STEM research and/or STEM engagement.  Learned of community interest in using art to connect students to STEM.
  6. Making meaningful connections with students and faculty to bridge the gap for mentorship to occur.
  7. Should be more people of color working in these job fields, as well as more people needing to discuss issues regarding limitations put forth against people of color.
  8. Conference helped me gain a better understanding of NSF's priorities and mindset regarding breaking barriers in STEM education and provided perspective from award recipients.

Regarding current authentic connections, the majority declared they have more than 1 colleague to receive support from for all ten survey categories. Furthermore, 100% of stated they have at least “A few (2-3 colleagues)” to help provide support regarding Intellectual Feedback. More than 45% said they have “A network of colleagues (4 or more)” to provide support in the area of Intellectual Community. Networks were weaker in the areas of colleagues providing safe spaces, e.g., to freely talk and not be judged, and accountability, having colleagues who would ensure one produces quality and timely progress. Only 18% indicated having a network of colleagues who served these roles.

Throughout the project, an email list was created to distribute various funding opportunities to the network of faculty of color.  Recorded sessions from the conferences included NSF program officers, STEM industry experts, and successfully funded faculty of color discussing funding opportunities. Project leaders also acted as a grantsmanship resource. Additionally, network connections such as the Pennsylvania State System of Higher Education Frederick Douglass Institute, HBCU Incubators, Philadelphia LS-AMP and Morgan State University we raised awareness for the need to identify faculty of color's research interests and begin to build a database to establish further connections within PASSHE.


Last Modified: 09/05/2023
Modified by: Mae Stephens
